member.name: T:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel
member.summary: Indicates the level of logging

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel.Trace
member.summary:
Use trace messages for intricate detail that you only really need when digging REALLY deep into a problem.
But try NOT to use this too much.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel.Debug
member.summary: Use debug messages for detailed.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel.Information
member.summary: Use information messages for mundane but USEFUL information.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel.Warning
member.summary: Warnings are for when things aren't quite right and someone should pay attention - but not an actual error

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel.Error
member.summary: Errors are for things that are wrong, unexpected exceptions and checked for, i.e. anticipated errors

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel.Critical
member.summary: Critical is REALLY BAD.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel.Fatal
member.summary: Reserve fatal errors for you've decided that you're dumping out of an application!

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel.Audit
member.summary: A special type of logging, audits can be extracted separately.

member.name: T:Moonrise.Logging.Logger
T:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel
member.summary: The reporting level to use. Log messages not covered by the reporting level will not get output. Note that Audit messages will ALWAYS be output, even if logging has been disabled!

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel.All
member.summary: All messages will be output (effectively the same as Trace)

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel.Trace
F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel.Debug
member.summary: All messages of Debug and higher (, , , ) will be output

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel.Information
member.summary: All messages of Information and higher (, , ) will be output. Can also be read as an enum of "Info".

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel.Warning
member.summary: All messages of Warning and higher (, ) will be output. Can also be read as an enum of "Warn".

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel.Error
member.summary: All messages of Error and higher () will be output

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel.Critical
member.summary: Only messages of Critical will be output

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel.Fatal
member.summary: Only messages of Fatal will be output.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ReportingLevel.Off
member.summary: No messages will be output, except Audit messages

member.summary: Keeps track of the indent in use where we start to log entry and exit points

member.summary: The maximum number of loggers that can be chained together

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Logger._OriginalLogger
member.summary: Maintains the actual logging provider

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.AuditProvider
member.summary: The root . Only the first auditor to be assigned will be accepted. Additional auditors can be managed via the property of your . If you need to replace the original auditor you will need to use as subsequent settings via will only affect the current thread.
member.remarks: If you set to null, then currently the auditor on ALL threads will be nulled out. Basically this shouldn't be done, but you MIGHT in a testing environment where you're using mocked loggers!

members.member:
Determines if logging is enabled or not. A way to remove MOST of the small overhead of logging without removing/commenting out logging statements.
If Disabled, each log statement will exit ASAP. If not Disabled, logging will behave as normal.

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Enabled
member.summary: Disabled works better as a property internally, Enabled works better externally. It's all the same thing!

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.LogMethodName
member.summary:
Indicates if the name of the method that calls one of the logging methods (Debug, Info, Warning, Error or Fatal) will be displayed as a prefix in the log message.
NOTE: This will only be the method name, and will not include the class or namespace!

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.LogProvider
member.summary: The root . Only the first logger to be assigned will be accepted. Additional loggers can be managed via the property of your . If you need to replace the original logger you will need to use as subsequent settings via will only affect the current thread.
member.remarks: If you set to null, then currently the logger on ALL threads will be nulled out. Basically this shouldn't be done, but you MIGHT in a testing environment where you're using mocked auditors!

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.MainLogProvider
member.summary: Let's you access the main thread's original log provider. Use this sparingly. It doesn't offer you the static convenience functions but IF you need to get this, then you can!

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.MaxChainedLoggers
member.summary: The maximum number of loggers in the NextLogger logging chain - Defaults to 3. You need a seriously good reason to change this! Also stops NextLogger loops.

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.OutputLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the current logging output level

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.StackTracingEnabled
member.summary: Allows stack tracing to be switched on and off - as in supressing or allowing the output of

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.UseConsoleOutput
member.summary: Determines if we should use Console output in addition to the LogProvider. Needs to be set AFTER the LogProvider has been determined.

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.UseContext
member.summary: Determines if any context is going to be printed in front of messages. If False, any scope WILL be logged at the point of the scope and indentation will be used instead.

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.UseThreadId
member.summary: Determines if the log message is to be prefixed with the thread id.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Clone
member.summary: Creates a new object that is a copy of the current instance.
member.remarks: As a user of the library you don't need to worry about this method. It is used when creating a logger per thread which means you can ALWAYS use Logger.Xxx and be sure that you have a thread-aware-safe logger for your current thread.
member.returns: A new object that is a copy of this instance.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.LogThis(Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel,System.String,System.String,Moonrise.Logging.LogTag,System.String)
member.summary:
Logs an error message to the console.
As a default ILoggingProvider, this is the default console logging if no other logger is provided.
member.param: The thread identifier - if is false, this will be empty.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Initialise(Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Config,Moonrise.Logging.ILoggingProvider,Moonrise.Logging.IAuditProvider)
member.summary: A one-shot initialisation using the specified configuration.
member.param: The audit provider, defaults to NULL - which means an calls to will be logged as an Audit message.
member.remarks: Each of the properties in the config can be set individually, this just makes that initialisation a bit more compact, especially if you've read the config as an object from a settings file.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ActivateLogTag(Moonrise.Logging.LogTag)
member.summary: Activates the log tag by adding it to the list of those already active.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ActivateLogTags(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: Activates the log tags by adding the supplied tags to those already active. If you want to reset the list, pass a null so you can start again.
member.param: The tag names or null to reset the list.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.DeactivateLogTag(Moonrise.Logging.LogTag)
member.summary: Deactivates the log tag by removing it from the list of those already active.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.DeactivateLogTags(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String})
member.summary: Deactivates the log tags by removing the supplied tags from those already active.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Args(System.Object[])
member.summary: Converts any number of args into an array of objects. Useful from time to time!
member.param: As many whatevers as you want
member.returns: The args as an object array

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Audit(System.String,System.Object,Moonrise.Logging.LogTag,Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel,System.String)
member.summary:
Logs an object in JSON format as a . It also passes the object to the which may wish to audit the actual object.
Note, this override of Audit will be used unless a more specific override is used. i.e. It will not JSON a String! Audit messages are log messages with a level of Audit. Audit is the highest level log message and will ALWAYS be logged, even if Logging has been disabled. Different s MAY decide to also treat Audit messages differently, however in addition you CAN also supply an (or chain of them) which will only be passed Audit messages via .
Also you don't need to log AND audit as the audit message will be logged and if you supply an auditLevel other than then the message will be prefixed with that level. So, you can audit errors and info. Unlikely you'd want to audit Debug but you could!
member.param: The message to accompany the audit
The object to be logged using JSON
The log tag. Unlike for Logging, auditing will always audit so the logTag can be used for extra information by the where required.
The name of the caller of this Audit.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Context(System.String,Moonrise.Logging.LogTag,System.String)
member.summary:
Starts a new nested scoped threaded context.
Usage:
using (Logger.Context()){code} or Logger.Context("whatever")
Logger.UseContext = true will then prepend all messages within context with "My Method : ". Context is scoped and nested. Logger.UseContext = false (default) will log the context and indent messages, but not include the context before every message!
member.param: The log tag scope - let's you also incorporate a log tag scope.
The caller context - defaults to the name of the caller
member.returns: A that SHOULD be used in a using statement

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Context(Moonrise.Logging.LogTag,System.String)
member.summary:
Starts a new nested scoped threaded context.
Usage:
using (Logger.Context()){code} or Logger.Context("whatever")
Logger.UseContext = true will then prepend all messages within context with "My Method : ". Context is scoped and nested. Logger.UseContext = false (default) will log the context and indent messages, but not include the context before every message!
member.param: The log tag scope - let's you also incorporate a log tag scope.
The caller context - defaults to the name of the caller
member.returns: A that SHOULD be used in a using statement

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Context(System.Object[],Moonrise.Logging.LogTag,System.String)
member.summary:
Starts a new nested scoped threaded context.
Usage:
using (Logger.Context()){code} or Logger.Context("whatever")
Logger.UseContext = true will then prepend all messages within context with "My Method : ". Context is scoped and nested. Logger.UseContext = false (default) will log the context and indent messages, but not include the context before every message!
Utilise Logger.(args,..) to pass arguments.
member.param: The log tag scope - let's you also incorporate a log tag scope.
The context - defaults to the name of the caller.
member.returns: A that SHOULD be used in a using statement

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.ScopedLogTag(Moonrise.Logging.LogTag,System.String)
member.param: The log tag to scope - if null, a LogTag will be created of the same name as the caller's name - Not really recommended though.
The caller context - defaults to the name of the caller
member.returns: A that SHOULD be used in a using statement

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.Trace(System.String,Moonrise.Logging.LogTag,System.String)
member.summary:
Logs the specified message as a .
Try not to use this too often for DETAIL, use Debug in preference UNLESS YOU NEED LOTS OF DETAIL
member.param: The method name of the caller. Will be displayed if is true.

members.member:
Logs any object using JSON as a . This will log the field name and value of the object. IF YOU CALL THIS MAKE SURE YOU HAVE A REFERENCE TO NewtonSoft.Json
Note, this override of Log will be used unless a more specific override is used. i.e. It will not JSON an Exception or a String! The object to be logged using JSON An optional log tag. The method name of the caller. Will be displayed if is true.

member.summary: Logs the specified object as a JSON string, as a .
member.param: The method name of the caller. Will be displayed if is true.

members.member:
Logs an exception as a .
The exception whose message and stack trace will be logged. The message to put in front of the exception message. The method name of the caller. Will be displayed if is true. Note however that the stack trace will be printed the first time this exception is logged. If it is logged subsequently, simply the message will be logged, not the stack trace. The HelpLink field (often unused) is used to flag this. If it is used, then you'll always get the stack trace.

member.param: The method name of the caller. Will be displayed if is true.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.JsonIt(System.Object)
member.summary: Gets an object in JSON format, prefixed by the name of the type of the object. IF YOU CALL THIS MAKE SURE YOU HAVE A REFERENCE TO NewtonSoft.Json. Do NOT use this to Json serialise things!
member.returns: It's JSON equivalent - Deeply nested/recursive objects are not always good candidates, nor those with certain attributes, but generally this works quite well.

members.member:
Outputs a "----------- side lined ----------------------" string to the logger. This will always come out!
The message to appear "titled" - Can have argument placeholders! Any arguments. The whole line will be 79/80 chars total with the message centered in the ----- lines ------

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.Logger.LocalLogger.Dispose
member.summary: Performs application-defined tasks associated with freeing, releasing, or resetting unmanaged resources. In this case, restoring the that WAS in use.

member.name: T:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider
member.summary: A Basic File Logger that will write logging text to a file. If the directory is invalid or anything it will simply not write.

member.name: T:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.Cycle
member.summary: Determines how filenames will get recycled. When a filename is recycled any previous file of the same name is overwritten.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.Cycle.Always
member.summary: Same filename is recycled every run - i.e. previous run's file is deleted. Nothing is added to the filename.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.Cycle.Daily
member.summary: Same filename is recycled every day. Nothing is added to the filename.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.Cycle.Weekly
member.summary: Same filename is recycled every week. "_ddd" for the 3 character day name is added before the file extension.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.Cycle.Monthly
member.summary: Same filename is recycled every month. "_DD" for the day of the month is added before the file extension.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.Cycle.Yearly
member.summary: Same filename is recycled every year. "_MMDD" for the month and day of the month is added before the file extension.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.Cycle.Never
member.summary: The filename is "never" recycled. "_YYYYMMDD" for the year, month and day of the month is added before the file extension.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.Cycle.ByCount
member.summary:
The filename is "never" recycled and a new log file is created every X messages. "_YYYYMMDDThhmmss" for the year, month and day of the month and time of creation is added before the file extension.
The format for the datetime part of the filename can be set via .

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.lockObject
member.summary: The lock object to use to single thread file writing.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider._cloned
member.summary: Indicates if an instance is a cloned instance or the original

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider._dateTimeProvider
member.summary: The date time provider, for generating timestamps and filenames.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.config
member.summary: The retained initial configuration, in case of needing to

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider._count
member.summary: The count of the number of messages logged in a given file.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.LoggingProviders.BasicFileLogProvider.FormatLogMsg(System.DateTime,Moonrise.Logging.LoggingLevel,System.String,System.String,Moonrise.Logging.LogTag,System.String)
member.summary:
In cases where you want to use a log file will generally do everything, however if you want more precise control over formatting the message - perhaps for later ingestion by LogStash/ElasticSearch - then this override will allow that.
NOTE: This method is only called AFTER all of the appropriate logging enablement checks have been performed so all you need to do is format the message.
member.param: The date time of the logging message. This time is consistent with the one used to generate the filename!
The log tag used. NOTE: LogTag filtering HAS ALREADY BEEN APPLIED.
The message passed to the logging function.
member.returns: A formatted string to be written out.

member.name: T:Moonrise.Logging.LogTag
member.summary:
Enables more granular logging control, by allowing (or not), logging associated with different s.
Usage:
Define in some functional group global class a LogTag instance with a "unique-ish" name. Pass this tag in those specific logging calls.
In your logging initialisation phase, pass a list of strings with the tags you want allowed to be logged. All non-tagged logs will still work, however any tagged logs not in that list will not be logged. The usual logging level still applies though.
We use tag instances rather than simply strings, as they're easier to make consistent and not have misspled tag names!

member.name: T:Moonrise.Logging.LogTag.Scoped
member.summary: A that is scoped within the thread.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The value which will be the current NestedThreadGlobal value.

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.LogTag.beenChecked
member.summary: Prevents infinte looping if a tag directly or indirectly is nested beneath itself.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.LogTag.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.LogTag.#ctor(System.String,Moonrise.Logging.LogTag)
member.summary:
Initializes a new instance of the class. Use this version if you want to nest this tag under another existing tag.
If a parent is active, all nested tags are also considered active.
NOTE: LogTags are clever enough not to loop forever when checking if parent tags are active but there's no other checking for how you manage your nesting, so be sensible.
member.param: A parent log tag so that you can group and nest tags.

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.LogTag.#ctor(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Moonrise.Logging.LogTag},Moonrise.Logging.LogTag)
member.summary:
Initializes a new instance of the class. Use this version if you want to nest other tags underneath this tag.
If a parent is active, all nested tags are also considered active.
NOTE: LogTags are clever enough not to loop forever when checking if parent tags are active but there's no other checking for how you manage your nesting, so be sensible.
member.param: The child log tags, each of which will be updated to make this tag their parent.

member.name: P:Moonrise.Logging.LogTag.Parent
member.summary: The parent tag indicating the tag is nested

member.summary: The scoped parent tag indicating the tag is nested in scope

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.LogTag.Scope
member.summary: Creates a new tag that is scoped within the current thread. This results in all non tagged logs within this scope being automatically tagged. This is a way of controlling ALL logging that might occur within scope without needing to add tags to each statement.

member.name: T:Moonrise.Logging.ScopeContext
member.summary:
Allows a context scope to be put into place for log messages.
Usage:
using (new Context("My Method")){code}
Logger.UseContext = true will then prepend all messages within context with "My Method : ". Context is scoped and nested

member.summary: Constructs a for logging. Messages logged within this scope will either be indented or have the scope name prefixed. See also
member.param: A name for the scope we are entering. It might be a method name, it might be something else to identify the scope your logging
The log tag to apply to this scope. Defaults to null, i.e. no log tag applied

A list of values you want to be logged as the arguments - typically to your method

member.name: M:Moonrise.Logging.ScopeContext.Disposing

member.name: T:Moonrise.Logging.Util.ScopedNestableThreadGlobalSingleton`1
member.summary:
Provides scoped, nestable, thread global values.
Scoped because any call to get the value (via a static) that occurs somewhere INSIDE the using scope will get that value.
Nestable because if you open another scope (through an interior/nested using) then THAT becomes the value anything inside of THAT scope will receive whereas once outside of THAT using scope the value for the PREVIOUS scope is the static value.
Thread because a is used as the backing store and so each scopes within different threads are just for that thread.
Global because it's sort of acting like a global variable!
Another way of thinking about this class is that it is a smuggler. It can smuggle values way down into call heirarchies without you needing to retrofit paramters to pass to each call. You know the way you can use class variables for temporary working purposes without them being true properties/attributes of that class (from the design rather than language persepective here)? Well, a is really the same thing, but for a thread. Kinda!
Usage:
public class SUT : NestableThreadGlobalSingleton<string>{public SUT(string value) : base(value){}
Wrap any significant "outer code" with
using (new SUT("value")) { YOUR CODE }
Then anywhere, even deep, within YOUR CODE you can get the current nested, threaded global value via SUT.CurrentValue()

member.name: F:Moonrise.Logging.Util.ScopedNestableThreadGlobalSingleton`1.ThreadedCurrentGlobal
member.summary: The current "thing". This is stored on a per thread basis.
